main_text:
The Goals and Open Questions of Johannsen (1911)
2. The Goals and Open Questions of Johannsen (1911)

Marcel Weber (2014) notes that, because many areas of modern biology
“are profoundly experimental disciplines, an increased attention
[in philosophy of biology] to the experiment in biology was
inevitable” (see also entry on
 gene).
 Yet, how an area of biology becomes experimental in the first place
as well as the implications of that shift also warrant attention. A
recounting of Johannsen (1911) in this vein serves not only to
introduce his original genotype-phenotype distinction, but also to
point to various conceptual and methodological complexities that are
associated with redefining heredity on the basis of breeding
experiments. The detail in this section and the next is important not
as a matter of doing history, but to insert distance from the
predominant current-day meanings and establish a space in which modern
users of his terms can consider issues that had been left behind.
section_title: 2. The Goals and Open Questions of Johannsen (1911)
